isis.stitle: HYDRO-MAX™ BRAKE BOOSTER AND MASTER CYLINDER - INSTALL - BLEEDING HYDRAULIC BRAKE SYSTEM

svcproc.title: BLEEDING HYDRAULIC BRAKE SYSTEM

warning.para: When adding fluids, take care to identify fluids (power steering fluid or brake fluid) and use only in the proper system. Discard all fluid bled or drained from either system. Do not use for refill, cleaning or any other purpose. Failure to observe these precautions could result in failure of the brake system, with resultant personal injury and/or property damage.

note.para: If both the brake fluid system and Hydro-Max™ booster system require bleeding, bleed the booster system first. Refer to BLEEDING HYDRO-MAX™ BOOSTER AND BACKUP PUMP ASSEMBLY

svcproc.para: The hydraulic brake system must be free of air to function properly. If air becomes mixed with brake fluid, excess pedal travel will result since air in the hydraulic system compresses. A bleeder screw is provided at each caliper assembly for removal of any air in the hydraulic brake system.

Bleeding the hydraulic brake system expels brake fluid and any air from the hydraulic system at one or more bleed points. Since the brake master cylinder reservoir is at the highest point in the brake system and there are no residual check valves in the system, the weight of the brake fluid will create fluid flow when a bleeder screw is opened. Thus, "gravity flow bleeding" of the hydraulic system can be accomplished. It is important that the master cylinder reservoir fluid level be maintained while bleeding the brakes.
For bleeding, a supply of clean DOT 3 brake fluid is necessary. DO NOT reuse brake fluid that has been drained from the hydraulic brake system as the fluid may be contaminated.
It is recommended that the hydraulic brake system be thoroughly flushed with new brake fluid whenever repairs are performed to be assured that hydraulic brake system is filled with clean fluid.
To flush the system, use bleeding procedures outlined herein and flush new brake fluid through system until it appears clean.
The following bleeding sequence is recommended, to reduce the possibility of missing a caliper assembly: right rear, left rear, right front, left front.
Brake fluid level in the master cylinder reservoir should be touching the bottom of the half cylindrical portion of either of the port openings.
Gravity flow bleeding of the hydraulic brake system requires only one person and NO pressure bleeder.

Install a clear plastic tube over the bleeder screw where bleeding operation is being performed and insert the opposite end of the tube into a container to catch the fluid. Open bleeder screw at caliper furthest away from master cylinder (right rear). Observe flow of fluid through the tube. When air bubbles no longer appear and a steady flow of clean fluid is present, that brake group is free of air. Close bleeder screw. Tighten to 8 to 15 lbf-ft (10 to 20 N•m).
Frequently check brake fluid level as air will be reintroduced into the system if the reservoir is allowed to empty.

When the bleeding procedure is complete. Fill master cylinder reservoir with brake fluid. When brake fluid touches the bottom of the half cylindrical portion of either of the fill port openings, the master cylinder is full. Loosen each brake line hex fitting (Item 5) enough to allow brake fluid to seep out past the fittings. When seepage starts, tighten fittings. Tighten to 16 to 17 lbf-ft (22 to 23 N•m).

note.para: If entire system has been drained, it may be necessary to slightly depress the brake pedal to initially start the fluid flow when bleeding the brake system.

caution.para: If pressure bleeding the system, do not exceed 35 psi.
